title: What is Leukemia?
description: Learn the fundamentals of leukemia and how it affects your blood and body.

questions.questionText: Leukemia is a cancer that primarily affects which part of the body?
questions.explanation: Leukemia is a cancer of blood-forming tissues, including bone marrow and the lymphatic system. It causes abnormal white blood cell production.

questions.questionText: Leukemia is contagious and can spread from person to person.
questions.explanation: Leukemia is NOT contagious. It's caused by genetic mutations in blood cells, not by any virus or bacteria that can spread.

questions.questionText: Which type of blood cell is most affected in leukemia?
questions.explanation: In leukemia, the bone marrow produces abnormal white blood cells (leukocytes) that don't function properly and crowd out healthy cells.

questions.questionText: Leukemia originates in the _____, where blood cells are made.
questions.explanation: Bone marrow is the spongy tissue inside bones where all blood cells are produced. Leukemia begins when mutations occur in this tissue.

questions.questionText: Leukemia can occur in both children and adults.
questions.explanation: Leukemia affects people of all ages. In fact, it is one of the most common cancers in children, but certain types are more prevalent in adults.

title: Types of Leukemia
description: Discover the four main types of leukemia and what makes each one unique.

questions.questionText: Which leukemia type is most common in children?
questions.explanation: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) is the most common cancer in children, though it can occur in adults too.

questions.questionText: What does 'acute' mean in the context of leukemia?
questions.explanation: 'Acute' leukemia progresses quickly and requires immediate treatment. 'Chronic' leukemia develops more slowly.

questions.questionText: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is most common in older adults.
questions.explanation: CLL predominantly affects adults over 60 and is rarely seen in children. It's one of the most common leukemias in the Western world.

questions.questionText: AML stands for:
questions.explanation: AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia) is a fast-growing cancer that starts in myeloid cells.

questions.questionText: There are _____ main types of leukemia classified by speed of progression and cell type.
questions.explanation: The four main types are ALL, AML, CLL, and CML — classified as either acute or chronic, and either lymphocytic or myeloid.

title: Early Warning Signs
description: Recognize the early symptoms of leukemia that you should never ignore.

questions.questionText: Which of these is a common early sign of leukemia?
questions.explanation: Persistent fatigue is one of the most common early signs of leukemia, caused by anemia from reduced red blood cell production.

questions.questionText: Frequent infections can be a warning sign of leukemia.
questions.explanation: Abnormal white blood cells in leukemia don't fight infections properly, leading to frequent, severe, or unusual infections.

questions.questionText: Why do leukemia patients often experience unexplained bruising or bleeding?
options: Low platelet count from crowded bone marrow
questions.correctAnswer: Low platelet count from crowded bone marrow
questions.explanation: When leukemia cells crowd the bone marrow, fewer platelets are produced. Low platelet counts cause easy bruising and bleeding.

questions.questionText: Swollen lymph nodes in the neck, armpits, or groin can be a sign of leukemia.
questions.explanation: Swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) occur when leukemia cells accumulate in lymph nodes. They are usually painless.

questions.questionText: If you notice several of these symptoms together, what should you do?
options: Wait to see if they go away
questions.explanation: Early detection significantly improves treatment outcomes. Never ignore a combination of these symptoms.

title: Risk Factors
description: Understand what increases the risk of developing leukemia.

questions.questionText: Which genetic condition is associated with an increased risk of leukemia?
questions.explanation: Children with Down syndrome have a 10-20x higher risk of developing acute leukemia.

questions.questionText: Exposure to high levels of radiation increases the risk of leukemia.
questions.explanation: Radiation exposure significantly increases leukemia risk, particularly AML.

questions.questionText: Which chemical exposure is linked to leukemia risk?
questions.explanation: Benzene is found in cigarette smoke and gasoline. Long-term exposure is strongly linked to AML.

questions.questionText: Smoking is a risk factor for leukemia.
questions.explanation: Smoking exposes the body to benzene and other carcinogens, increasing the risk of AML by approximately 40%.

questions.questionText: Having a family history of leukemia slightly increases your _____ of developing it.
questions.explanation: While most leukemia cases are not directly inherited, having a first-degree relative with certain types does increase your personal risk.

title: Treatment Options
description: Explore the main treatments available for leukemia patients today.

questions.questionText: What is the most common first-line treatment for acute leukemia?
questions.explanation: Chemotherapy uses drugs to kill or stop the growth of cancer cells. It is the primary treatment for most leukemia types.

questions.questionText: A bone marrow transplant can potentially cure some types of leukemia.
questions.explanation: Stem cell (bone marrow) transplants replace diseased bone marrow with healthy donor cells and can offer a cure for eligible patients.

questions.questionText: What does targeted therapy do differently from traditional chemotherapy?
options: It targets specific cancer cell mutations with fewer side effects
questions.correctAnswer: It targets specific cancer cell mutations with fewer side effects
questions.explanation: Targeted therapies attack specific proteins in cancer cells, causing less damage to healthy cells than traditional chemo.

questions.questionText: Imatinib (Gleevec) is a famous targeted therapy drug for treating _____.
questions.explanation: Imatinib transformed CML from a fatal disease into a manageable condition by blocking the BCR-ABL protein.

questions.questionText: Immunotherapy helps the patient's own immune system fight leukemia cells.
questions.explanation: CAR-T cell therapy engineers the patient's own T-cells to recognize and destroy leukemia cells.

title: How Blood Cells Work
description: Understand how healthy blood cells are made and what goes wrong in leukemia.

questions.questionText: What are the three main types of blood cells?
questions.explanation: Blood contains red blood cells (carry oxygen), white blood cells (fight infection), and platelets (help clotting).

questions.questionText: All blood cells originate from _____ cells in the bone marrow.
questions.explanation: Hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow are the source of all blood cell types. In leukemia, their development goes wrong.

questions.questionText: What is the role of red blood cells?
questions.explanation: Red blood cells contain hemoglobin which binds to oxygen and transports it from the lungs to all tissues.

questions.questionText: In leukemia, abnormal cells crowd out healthy blood cells in the bone marrow.
questions.explanation: Leukemic cells multiply uncontrollably and take up space in the bone marrow, leaving little room for healthy red cells, white cells, and platelets.

questions.questionText: What is the lifespan of a typical red blood cell?
questions.explanation: Red blood cells live about 120 days before being recycled by the spleen. The bone marrow must constantly produce new ones.

title: Diagnosing Leukemia
description: Learn how doctors detect and diagnose leukemia using modern tests.

questions.questionText: What is the first test usually done to detect leukemia?
questions.explanation: A CBC measures the levels of red cells, white cells, and platelets. Abnormal numbers — especially too many white cells — can indicate leukemia.

questions.questionText: A bone marrow biopsy is needed to confirm a leukemia diagnosis.
questions.explanation: A bone marrow biopsy takes a small sample from the hip bone. It confirms the type and extent of leukemia and guides treatment decisions.

questions.questionText: What does a bone marrow biopsy examine?
questions.explanation: The biopsy extracts a small sample of bone marrow, usually from the hip bone, to examine the blood-forming cells under a microscope.

questions.questionText: CBC stands for Complete Blood _____.
questions.explanation: A Complete Blood Count (CBC) is a standard blood test that provides counts of all cell types and is the first step in diagnosing blood disorders.

questions.questionText: Which test identifies specific genetic mutations in leukemia cells?
questions.explanation: Cytogenetic analysis examines chromosomes in leukemia cells to identify mutations like the Philadelphia chromosome in CML, guiding targeted therapy.

title: Lifestyle & Prevention
description: Discover lifestyle changes that can reduce your leukemia risk.

questions.questionText: Which lifestyle change most directly reduces leukemia risk?
questions.explanation: Smoking contains benzene and dozens of carcinogens that increase AML risk by ~40%. Quitting smoking is the single most impactful lifestyle change.

questions.questionText: Avoiding unnecessary radiation exposure (e.g., excessive X-rays) can reduce leukemia risk.
questions.explanation: While medical X-rays use very low doses, unnecessary repeated exposure to ionizing radiation should be avoided to minimize cumulative risk.

questions.questionText: Workers in which industry face higher benzene exposure risk?
questions.explanation: Workers in petroleum refining, rubber manufacturing, and chemical plants face higher benzene exposure. Proper protective equipment is essential.

questions.questionText: Regular medical check-ups can help detect leukemia at an earlier, more treatable stage.
questions.explanation: Routine blood tests during check-ups can catch abnormal cell counts early. Early-stage leukemia generally has much better treatment outcomes.

questions.questionText: Maintaining a healthy immune system through diet and exercise may help your body fight _____ cell changes.
questions.explanation: A strong immune system helps detect and destroy abnormal cells before they become cancerous, though it cannot prevent all leukemia cases.

title: Living with Leukemia
description: Tips and guidance for patients and families coping with a leukemia diagnosis.

questions.questionText: What is 'remission' in leukemia treatment?
options: No cancer cells are detectable in the body
questions.correctAnswer: No cancer cells are detectable in the body
questions.explanation: Remission means cancer cells are no longer detectable in tests. Complete remission is the main goal of treatment, though monitoring continues.

questions.questionText: Mental health support is an important part of leukemia care.
questions.explanation: A leukemia diagnosis causes significant emotional stress. Counseling, support groups, and mental health care are essential parts of comprehensive treatment.

questions.questionText: Why should leukemia patients avoid crowded places during chemotherapy?
options: Chemo weakens the immune system, raising infection risk
questions.correctAnswer: Chemo weakens the immune system, raising infection risk
questions.explanation: Chemotherapy reduces white blood cell counts, making patients highly vulnerable to infections. Avoiding crowds helps prevent potentially life-threatening illnesses.

questions.questionText: Joining a _____ group connects patients with others who understand the leukemia journey.
questions.explanation: Support groups — in person or online — provide emotional comfort, practical advice, and a sense of community for patients and their families.

questions.questionText: Family members of leukemia patients may also benefit from counseling.
questions.explanation: Caring for a loved one with leukemia is emotionally and physically demanding. Counseling and caregiver support programs help families cope.

title: Spreading Awareness
description: Learn how you can help spread leukemia awareness and support research.

questions.questionText: September is recognized as which awareness month?
questions.explanation: September is Blood Cancer Awareness Month, dedicated to raising awareness about leukemia, lymphoma, and myeloma worldwide.

questions.questionText: Donating blood can help leukemia patients who need transfusions.
questions.explanation: Leukemia patients frequently need red blood cell and platelet transfusions. Regular blood donation from healthy donors directly saves lives.

questions.questionText: Joining a bone marrow donor registry can help which patients?
options: Patients who need a stem cell transplant
questions.correctAnswer: Patients who need a stem cell transplant
questions.explanation: Many leukemia patients need a matched stem cell donor. Registering as a bone marrow donor could save someone's life.

questions.questionText: Wearing _____ ribbons is a symbol of support for blood cancer awareness.
questions.explanation: Orange ribbons symbolize leukemia awareness. Wearing one helps start conversations and spread awareness in your community.

questions.questionText: Sharing accurate leukemia information on social media helps reduce stigma and encourages early diagnosis.
questions.explanation: Spreading accurate, compassionate information helps others recognize symptoms earlier and reduces the fear and stigma surrounding cancer diagnoses.

title: Chemotherapy Explained
description: A deep dive into how chemotherapy works and what patients can expect.

questions.questionText: How does chemotherapy kill cancer cells?
questions.explanation: Chemotherapy drugs target cells that divide rapidly — which is a key characteristic of cancer cells. Unfortunately, some healthy fast-dividing cells (like hair follicles) are affected too.

questions.questionText: Hair loss is a common side effect of chemotherapy.
questions.explanation: Hair follicle cells divide rapidly, so they are often affected by chemo. Hair typically regrows after treatment ends.

questions.questionText: What are the two main phases of chemotherapy for ALL?
questions.explanation: Induction therapy aims to achieve remission quickly. Maintenance therapy continues for months or years to prevent relapse and kill remaining cancer cells.

questions.questionText: Chemotherapy is usually given in _____ to allow the body time to recover between treatments.
questions.explanation: Treatment cycles typically last a few weeks, followed by a rest period. This allows healthy cells to recover while keeping pressure on cancer cells.

questions.questionText: Nausea and vomiting are common side effects of chemotherapy that can be managed with medication.
questions.explanation: Anti-nausea (antiemetic) drugs are routinely given alongside chemotherapy to significantly reduce nausea and vomiting.

title: The Philadelphia Chromosome
description: Understand one of the most important genetic discoveries in leukemia research.

questions.questionText: The Philadelphia chromosome is most associated with which leukemia type?
questions.explanation: The Philadelphia chromosome is found in over 90% of CML patients. It's caused by a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22.

questions.questionText: What abnormal protein does the Philadelphia chromosome produce?
questions.explanation: The translocation creates the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which produces an overactive tyrosine kinase that drives uncontrolled cell division.

questions.questionText: The discovery of the Philadelphia chromosome led to the development of targeted therapies like imatinib.
questions.explanation: Understanding that BCR-ABL drives CML allowed scientists to design imatinib (Gleevec), which specifically blocks this protein — a landmark in precision medicine.

questions.questionText: The Philadelphia chromosome results from a translocation between chromosomes 9 and _____.
questions.explanation: This chromosomal swap — called t(9;22) — merges part of chromosome 9 onto chromosome 22, creating the shorter Philadelphia chromosome.

questions.questionText: In which city was the Philadelphia chromosome first discovered?
questions.explanation: It was discovered in 1960 by Peter Nowell and David Hungerford at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia — hence the name.

title: CAR-T Cell Therapy
description: Explore the revolutionary immunotherapy that reprograms your own immune cells to fight leukemia.

questions.questionText: What does CAR stand for in CAR-T therapy?
questions.explanation: CAR stands for Chimeric Antigen Receptor — an engineered protein added to T-cells that helps them recognize and attack specific cancer cells.

questions.questionText: In CAR-T therapy, the patient's own T-cells are used.
questions.explanation: T-cells are extracted from the patient, genetically engineered in a lab to express the CAR protein, then infused back into the patient to attack cancer cells.

questions.questionText: Which leukemia type was CAR-T therapy first approved for?
questions.explanation: In 2017, tisagenlecleucel (Kymriah) became the first CAR-T therapy approved by the FDA, specifically for children with relapsed ALL.

questions.questionText: CAR-T therapy is a form of _____ therapy because it uses the immune system to fight cancer.
questions.explanation: By engineering immune cells, CAR-T falls under immunotherapy — treatments that harness or enhance the immune system's ability to fight cancer.

questions.questionText: CAR-T therapy has shown complete remission in some patients who had no other treatment options.
questions.explanation: Clinical trials showed CAR-T achieved complete remission in up to 90% of children with relapsed ALL — remarkable results for patients with no other options.

title: Leukemia in Children
description: Learn about leukemia's impact on children and why early detection matters most.

questions.questionText: What percentage of all childhood cancers does leukemia account for?
questions.explanation: Leukemia accounts for roughly 30% of all cancers in children, making it the most common childhood cancer.

questions.questionText: The survival rate for childhood ALL has improved dramatically over the past 50 years.
questions.explanation: In the 1960s, childhood ALL was almost always fatal. Today, over 90% of children with ALL achieve complete remission thanks to modern treatment.

questions.questionText: At what age range is childhood leukemia most commonly diagnosed?
questions.explanation: Childhood leukemia peaks between ages 2-5, though it can occur at any age. The reasons for this age peak are still being studied.

questions.questionText: The 5-year survival rate for children with ALL is now over _____% in developed countries.
questions.explanation: Modern treatment protocols have achieved over 90% 5-year survival rates for childhood ALL, one of the great success stories in cancer medicine.

questions.questionText: Children tolerate leukemia treatment differently than adults and often recover more completely.
questions.explanation: Children generally tolerate intensive chemotherapy better than adults and have better outcomes partly due to biological differences in their leukemia cells.

title: Bone Marrow Transplant
description: Understand how stem cell transplants work and who they can help.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of high-dose chemotherapy before a bone marrow transplant?
options: To destroy the diseased bone marrow and make room for donor cells
questions.correctAnswer: To destroy the diseased bone marrow and make room for donor cells
questions.explanation: High-dose chemotherapy (conditioning) wipes out the patient's existing bone marrow, both destroying leukemia cells and creating space for the donor stem cells.

questions.questionText: An allogeneic transplant uses stem cells from a matched donor.
questions.explanation: Allogeneic means 'from another person'. A matched sibling or unrelated donor provides stem cells. The match is based on HLA (human leukocyte antigen) proteins.

questions.questionText: What is 'graft-versus-host disease' (GVHD)?
options: When the body rejects the transplant
When donor cells attack the patient's own tissues
When the immune system overreacts to chemo
questions.correctAnswer: When donor cells attack the patient's own tissues
questions.explanation: GVHD occurs when the donor's immune cells recognize the patient's body as foreign and attack it. It can range from mild to life-threatening.

questions.questionText: A transplant using the patient's own cells is called an _____ transplant.
questions.explanation: An autologous transplant collects the patient's own stem cells before high-dose chemo, then re-infuses them. It avoids GVHD but doesn't provide a graft-versus-leukemia effect.

questions.questionText: Finding a matched unrelated donor can take weeks to months.
questions.explanation: HLA matching is complex. International registries like DKMS and Be The Match search millions of volunteers to find the best match for patients.
